Award.AwardTitle: Operation of the HAWC Gamma-Ray Observatory
Award.AbstractNarration:
The High Altitude Water Cherenkov (HAWC) Gamma-ray Observatory is a wide field-of-view, continuously operating, teraelectronvolt (TeV) gamma-ray telescope that will explore the origin of cosmic rays, study the acceleration of particles in extreme physical environments, and search for new TeV physics. HAWC is under construction at an elevation of 4100 meters above sea level in Mexico by a collaboration of US and Mexican institutions. This award will fund operations that will begin in August 2013 even while construction is being completed. At the beginning of operations HAWC, with 100 Water Cherenkov Detectors, will be the most sensitive wide-field detector in the TeV range. During the first year of operation, HAWC's sensitivity will steadily increase as more detectors are brought online. When completed in the Fall of 2014 HAWC will consist of an array of the 250-300 detectors and will be more than an order of magnitude more sensitive than its predecessors. HAWC will monitor the northern sky and make coincident observations with other observatories including VERITAS, HESS, Magic, IceCube and the Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope for multi-wavelength and multi-messenger studies of the high-energy sky. HAWC will observe Galactic sources in the TeV energy range, detect diffuse emission from regions of the Galactic plane, observe known TeV active galactic nuclei and the brightest known gigaelectronvolt (GeV) gamma-ray bursts, and with its significant increase in sensitivity it is poised to discover new high-energy phenomena in the Universe.

Broader Impacts: HAWC is an all-sky instrument that will serve as a TeV 'finder' telescope for ground-based observatories, and it can be used to extend measurements of satellite-discovered sources to TeV energies. HAWC will build on the strong outreach record of Milagro to bring the high-energy astrophysics field to students and the general public. Since HAWC is a joint Mexican-American project, it presents an opportunity to attract Hispanic-American students to science and to particle astrophysics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The HAWC Observatory

The High Altitude Water Cherenkov (HAWC) Gamma-ray Observatory is a wide field of view, continuously operating TeV gamma-ray telescope that is exploring the origin of cosmic rays, studying the acceleration of particles in extreme physical environments, and searching for new physics at the TeV-PeV scale. The main HAWC detector array was completed on March 20, 2015. Since that time we have operated the detector at greater than 90% uptime. While taking, processing and analyzing nearly a petabyte of data a year, we continue to improve the sensitivity of the detector and the analysis chain. We regularly release new sky maps to the community, as well as issuing and responding to real-time alerts.

 HAWC has provided a new look at the TeV sky, discovering new sources and new source classes, setting new limits on dark matter and playing a crucial role in multi-messenger observations. HAWC is a unique survey instrument offering a view of the TeV sky that is orthogonal to the current array of IACT experiments and the upcoming CTA project. While HAWC has less instantaneous sensitivity to point sources when compared to IACTs, its wide field-of-view, and continuous operation give a much higher exposure, which leads to significant advantages when studying gamma-ray source variability, source extension of the order of the typical field-of-view of IACTs, and emission energy beyond 10 TeV.  HAWC provides daily unbiased monitoring of variable sources including nearby active galactic nuclei (AGN). HAWC is particularly well suited to study extended and diffuse sources, which are challenging targets for IACTs. 

Recent HAWC Results:

HAWC is a wide-field-of-view instrument that surveys more than half the sky every day. This makes it an ideal instrument to discover new sources of TeV gamma rays both in the galaxy and out. Shown in the attached figures are sky maps where many sources along the Galactic plane can be seen as well as AGNs Mrk 421 and Mrk 501. The data shown are from 1128 days of HAWC operation. This represents the deepest wide-field-of view survey the northern sky at TeV energies. 50 sources above 5σ are detected. More than 20 of these are new discoveries by HAWC. 

We have performed a survey of the Galactic plane at higher energies than IACTs and with better sensitivity for extended and hard spectrum sources. The attached figure shows the highest energy view of our galaxy ever seen revealing sources above 50 and 100 TeV. 

SS 433 is a micro-quasar which has been extensively studied in many wavelengths from radio to MeV. Its orientation with jets nearly perpendicular to our line of sight makes both jets visible. Previous observations by HESS and MAGIC set upper limits on TeV emission from the jets, and VERITAS reported a weak excess. HAWC has detected TeV emission from the SS 433 system where the lobes are spatially resolved. The TeV emission is localized to structures in the lobes, far from the center of the system where the jets are formed. We have measured photon energies of at least 25 TeV, and these are not Doppler boosted, because of the viewing geometry.



Broader Impacts:

 HAWC is one of the most visible science projects in Mexico. We have taken advantage of this by creating an extensive public outreach program in both English and Spanish aimed broadly at educational institutions from elementary school students, to undergraduates, to senior citizens in the US and Mexico. We have actively engaged students from high school to graduate school from both the US and Mexico in the construction, analysis, and operation of the HAWC detector and are working to attract under-represented groups to study in the field. HAWC has produced a number of videos for outreach (many can be found on YouTube) explaining HAWC in English and Spanish. These videos combined have had well over 100k views. 

In addition, we have developed web materials about HAWC and PA in both Spanish and English for use in both Mexico and the US. We have also worked with programs aimed to attract underrepresented groups to both Physics and Astronomy such as the GRAD-MAP program at UMD, (Graduate Resources for Advancing Diversity with Maryland Astronomy and Physics).
